item.title: Remote HF Antenna Switch
item.description:
Design

I wanted a remote antenna switch, and commercial models seem to be expensive relative to what I am willing to spend. I planned to combine an Arduino, ethernet shield with power over ethernet, and a board with four relays. This assumes that commonly available relay boards would work fine …
item.dc:creator: eheisman

item.title: Meteor Scatter Station
item.description:
Plans

One of those magical things that has kept me interested in ham radio all these years has been the idea of bouncing signals off of things, particularly those in space. I've long wanted to give meteor scatter a try, so I want to get my station set up for …

item.title: Garden Boxes
item.description: A couple of years ago we decided to move our vegetable garden to the front yard, with the goal of reducing the amount of lawn we had and making use of one of the sunnier and less utilized spots in our yard. Our existing raised beds had been build by …

item.title: Homemade house numbers - or, is a CNC machine worth it?
item.description: Around the time I started to get into woodworking, I bought a Shapeoko2 CNC machine during their crowdfunding campaign. I had mostly planned to use it for electronics projects, milling single layer circuit boards and making simple enclosures. My in-laws then asked for larger than normal house numbers as a …

item.title: Shop Improvements
item.description: My woodshop is the back half of my garage, which was added as an addition by some previous owner. There is an obvious gap between the front and back halfs, where a hole was framed up and cut open I've long wanted to make my shop more usable in the …

item.title: End grain cutting boards
item.description:
Two of the four cutting boards I made shown next to each other.

I started making a big end grain cutting board a way of saying thanks to a good friend who catered our baby shower and learned a lot of things along the way.

Concept

item.title: Hand planes
item.description: Before I started woodworking, I always thought handplanes were a quirky part of the woodworking hobby, something that people collected but not commonly used. I bought one #4 plane from Harbor Freight during my cutting board project to help square up the strips. I figured it was a lot cheaper …

item.title: Learning Tower
item.description:
Concept

I modified these plans from Ana White by removing the arch shape and using mortise and tenon joints instead of the pocket screws. I could have easily done it with the pocket screws and had a great result, but I wanted to challenge myself doing a whole bunch of …
item.dc:creator: eheisman

item.title: Toy cars
item.description: I have wanted to make more wooden toys for my kid, and after purchasing a used scroll saw, I was able to make a couple of toy cars like this out of some scrap elm I had in the shop. I had bought the wheels from a wood supply shop …

item.title: Desk
item.description:
Concept

In late 2020, I realized I was going to need a better desk to continue working from home with, so I decided it was time to finally build one. This had been a goal of mine when getting into woodworking, but given the circumstances, I thought it was a …
item.dc:creator: eheisman

item.title: Owl House
item.description:
A few years ago we decided to put a screech owl box in our big oak tree. We regularly hear them calling at night during the summer when our windows are open.

I found plans from WDFW and Cornell Lab of Ornithology, which I ended up using the WDFW plans …
item.dc:creator: eheisman

item.title: Workbench and Stand
item.description:
Here's a few bits of shop furniture I've built and my thoughts about what I would do different next time. I figure shop furniture is a great place to learn new techniques without worrying about aesthetics. I often use construction lumber and recycled materials for these.

Miter saw stand

item.title: Woodworking resources
item.description:
Video Channels

  • Rex Kruger (YouTube) - Rex's videos really taught me how to sharpen and use handplanes and I really appreciate his approach to making woodworking with hand tools more accessible.
  • Steve Ramsey (YouTube) - Lots of good introductory videos for power tool woodworking
  • New Yankee Workshop (not YouTube)

Books

item.title: What's here
item.description:
About Me

I'm a civil engineer (water resources engineer) by training who has been doing more and more software engineering work. My job consists of maintaining and upgrading computer models of watersheds and reserviors. When I am not doing that, I dabble in woodworking, birding, organic gardening, photography, and ham …
